content: The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for disclosure, limits on soft money of national political party committees, and miscellaneous provisions. It mandates additional disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, increased electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also sets limits on soft money, increases contribution limits, and provides for judicial review. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for disclosure, limits on soft money of national political party committees, and miscellaneous provisions such as prohibiting solicitation of political party soft money in Federal buildings, updating penalty amounts, and filing Senate reports with the Federal Election Commission. Additional monthly and quarterly disclosure reports are mandated. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" mandates additional monthly and quarterly disclosure reports for principal campaign committees. Monthly reports are due by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December, with a year-end report due by January 31 of the following year. The year-end report must be filed by January 31 of the following year, and quarterly reports are due by the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter, with the exception of the report for the quarter ending December 31, which must also be filed by January 31 of the following year. The year-end report must be filed by January 31 of the following year, and quarterly reports are due by the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter. National committees of political parties have specific reporting requirements. In amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act, quarterly reports are changed to monthly reports, and the term "calendar quarter" is replaced with "month". SEC. 102. REPORTING BY NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national and congressional political committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period. Political committees must separately itemize reporting for any person with receipts or disbursements exceeding $200 in a calendar year. Reporting periods for these requirements are specified. The political committee must separately itemize reporting for any person with receipts or disbursements exceeding $200 in a calendar year, following the reporting periods specified. SEC. 103 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require the Commission to make reports available on the Internet within 24 hours of receiving the information. SEC. 104 mandates public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make available for public inspection a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 now requires licensees to keep a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters of national importance, including details such as acceptance/rejection, rates, air date/time, purchased time class, and candidate information. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 mandates licensees to maintain records of requests for broadcast time for political matters, including details like rates, air date/time, purchased time class, and candidate information. Licensees are required to maintain a political file with details of broadcast time requests, including candidate information and purchaser details. This information must be retained for at least 2 years. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require the development and provision of software for filing reports at no cost to individuals required to file. The software must be used by those maintaining or filing reports. SEC. 201. LIMIT ON SOFT MONEY OF NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Amendment to Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to impose limits on soft money contributions by national political party committees. The provision imposes limits on donations to political party committees, restricting individuals from donating more than $60,000 in a calendar year. Additionally, it sets an aggregate limit on donor disbursements and allows for adjustments based on the price index after 2001. The provision sets a $60,000 aggregate limit on donor disbursements in a calendar year, with adjustments based on the price index after 2001. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Expedited Review: Members of Congress, candidates, national party committees, or those affected by a section of the Federal Election Campaign Act can challenge its constitutionality in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. Appeals on such cases can go directly to the Supreme Court. The enforcement of any provision of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 can be challenged in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. Appeals can go directly to the Supreme Court for expedited consideration. The enforcement of section 324 will be stayed during the legal proceedings. Enforcement of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act can be challenged in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. The enforcement will be stayed until the Supreme Court makes a final decision on the matter. This provision applies to actions filed within 30 days of the Act's effective date. SEC. 203: Increase in contribution limits. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including raising individual and political committee limits to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000, and multicandidate limits to $75,000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is being amended to increase contribution limits, including raising individual and political committee limits to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000, and multicandidate limits to $75,000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is being amended to increase contribution limits, including raising individual and political committee limits to $30,000 and $7,500, and multicandidate limits to $75,000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is being amended to increase contribution limits, with limitations under subsections (a) and (h) remaining in effect for a 2-year period. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is being amended to increase contribution limits, with the increased amounts remaining in effect for specific calendar years. The amendment also includes an increase in Senate candidate contribution limits for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for specific calendar years. Senate candidate contribution limits for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees are also increased. The amendments apply to calendar years starting after December 31, 2001, with specific provisions for years after December 31, 2002. SEC. 301 prohibits the solicitation of political party soft money in federal buildings. The amendment to Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, redefines the term "contribution" to include gifts, loans, or deposits of money in connection with federal elections or political committees. Additionally, Section 602(a)(4) is amended to prohibit donations within the scope of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include a prohibition on donations by any State, district, or local committee of a political party. Section 602(a)(4) of title 18, United States Code, is also amended to define donations as specified in section 607(c). SEC. 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust penalty amounts for inflation based on the price index. Each dollar amount will be increased annually, starting from 2001. This adjustment does not apply to the $25,000 amount under subsection (d). SEC. 303 requires Senate reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. SEC. 303 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require all designations, statements, and reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. Conforming amendments are made to sections 304 and 311(a)(4) of the Act.
